com.yashovardhan99.timeit

Class Stopwatch

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.yashovardhan99.timeit.Stopwatch

  • public class Stopwatch
extends Object
    The Stopwatch class is used for creating and using a simple stopwatch with basic features like : start, pause, resume and split. It allows you to send a TextView and automatically updates it every 0.1 seconds (or as set by you). You can also implement the custom OnTickListener to listen for time changes every time period. Threading on a separate thread is handled by the class itself. You just need to call appropriate methods to control the stopwatch.

    Created by Yashovardhan99 on 8/12/18 as a part of TimeIt.

    Version:
    1.2
    Author:
    Yashovardhan Dhanania
    See Also:
    Runnable

      • getClockDelay

        public long getClockDelay()
        Returns the currently set clock delay
        Returns:
        currently set clock delay in milliseconds (default: 100ms)
        Since:
        1.0

      • setClockDelay

        public void setClockDelay(long clockDelay)
        Set a custom clock delay to increase/decrease update frequency. Clock delay is the delay in between each successive clock update.
        Parameters:
        clockDelay - clock delay in milliseconds (default : 100ms)
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        Thread.sleep(long)

      • setDebugMode

        public void setDebugMode(boolean debugMode)
        Set whether to print debug logs or not. If enabled, it will log each time the time is updated.
        Parameters:
        debugMode - desired debugging status
        Since:
        1.0

      • setTextView

        public void setTextView(@Nullable
                        TextView textView)
        Allows you to set a textView where the stopwatch time is displayed. If not provided, or set to null, you need to manually display the time.
        Parameters:
        textView - the textView where you want to display the stopwatch time. Can be null.
        Since:
        1.0

      • setOnTickListener

        public void setOnTickListener(Stopwatch.OnTickListener onTickListener)
        Set an OnTickListener to listen for clock changes.
        Parameters:
        onTickListener - a reference to the interface implementation.
        Since:
        1.0

      • start

        public void start()
        Starts the stopwatch at the current time. Cannot be called again without calling stop() first.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the stopwatch has already been started.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        stop(), isStarted()

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stops the stopwatch. Stopwatch cannot be resumed from current time later.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if stopwatch has not been started yet.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        start(), isStarted()

      • pause

        public void pause()
        Pauses the stopwatch. Using this allows you to resume the stopwatch from the current state.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if stopwatch is already paused or not started yet.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        resume(), isPaused()

      • resume

        public void resume()
        Used to resume the stopwatch from the current time after being paused.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if stopwatch is not paused or not started yet.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        pause(), isPaused()

      • split

        public void split()
        Creates a new split/lap at the current time. Can even be called when stopwatch is paused.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if stopwatch is not started yet
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getSplits()
